definition: (of an actor) to inhabit one's role/to become the character/(of an audience) to get involved in the drama
to enter/to go into/to join/to become a member of/to confirm or agree with/abbr. for 入聲|入声[ru4 sheng1]

sentences.english: Direct your actors to stay in character. Ask them to study their characters.
sentences.chinese: 指导你的演员入戏，要他们研究角色。

sentences.english: I saw a good theme in a newspaper, which can be put into a drama.
sentences.chinese: 这个可以入戏的好题材是我从报纸上看到的。

sentences.english: Maybe, I can be an actor or a director, and be involved easily.
sentences.chinese: 也许我适合做演员，导演也行，容易入戏。

sentences.english: Did you feel comfortable pretty quickly or was it awkward 1 for most of the night?
sentences.chinese: 你觉得自己入戏很快还是大部分时间就光觉得了？

sentences.english: Have you been too involved in acting to be aware of the essence of ease and happiness?
sentences.chinese: 你是否已经入戏太深，忘掉了自在幸福的本质？

sentences.english: Songs like game, every word in the play, but it is too virtual.
sentences.chinese: 情歌象游戏，每句都入戏，可惜太虚拟。

definition: (of an actor) to disengage from the performance (e.g. after the show ends)/(of an audience) to lose interest in the performance
to put on a play/to perform/fig. to pretend/to feign
to develop/to evolve/to practice/to perform/to play/to act
to stir up emotion/to arouse sympathy/moving

(TV or movie) blooper/continuity error/(theater) to flub one's lines/unintended exposure of a body part/to be exposed (of a scheme or trick)/to reveal sth one intended to conceal through a slip of the tongue/to blow one's cover
The End (appearing at the end of a movie etc)
